audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing himself and the purpose of the video: a helpful guide for Android users experiencing installation issues due to limited storage. The speaker mentions getting a new phone and switching carriers, even briefly commenting on the camera's view of his face.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing a new phone, mentioning the small internal storage and his need to install apps on his 32 gigabyte SD card. The speaker's tone is conversational and somewhat frustrated.

The audio begins with a male speaker saying, "Um, so, after some much research, I found an article that literally just walked me through it". He continues by explaining he wants to make a video to show listeners how to install an internal SD card on an Android phone, without any further ado, he gets into it. He explains that his phone cannot install apps directly to the SD card or move certain apps there. The speaker notes that some apps can move to the SD card with no problem. Then he transitions into another example and says that a "flappy bird doesn't allow you to move to the SD card". He adds that he will help listeners "get that option" and allow them to move any application on their phone to the SD card. As an example, he describes how an app, "Tumbler", is "one that doesn't allow you to move to the SD card either".

The audio begins with one male speaker offering instructions, starting with "first thing you're going to want to do." He guides the listener through navigating app settings to find developer options, advising on how to activate them if they are not initially visible by tapping on the build number. The tone is informative and instructional. He briefly corrects himself, emphasizing it's the build number, not the software version, one should tap. The speaker then explains the process of unlocking the developer option and turning it on.

The clip features a single speaker, presumably male, explaining instructions in a straightforward tone, referencing "USB debugging" and needing to plug in a phone. The speaker notes the phone is plugged in, mentioning the sounds it makes when plugged in. The instructions continue, referencing the USB debugging connection. The scene transitions as the speaker mentions moving over to the computer.

The audio begins with a male speaker outlining the steps of a process. He transitions to describe how he's now at his computer, which is no longer being recorded with a "potato of a camera," but with recording software. He then says a pop-up will show up that needs to be closed.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker providing instructions about downloading the Java SE Development Kit and the SDK tools for Android, detailing the download process and subsequent installation steps. His tone is instructional and clear. Once the programs are installed, he guides the listener to the SDK manager and states what actions the listener should take with it.

The audio begins with a single male speaker giving instructions on how to use Java SDK tools and platform tools, mentioning to "check both of those and click install," and to install only two specific packages. He then instructs the listener to go back to the start menu, open the SDK tools folder, right click on the SDK manager, and open file location to the program's location. Moving on, he says to open platform tools and then to shift and right-click inside the folder to select the option "open command window here." The speaker concludes by providing the exact phrase to type: "ADB devices," and instructs the listener to press enter.

The audio clip contains one speaker, a male with an instructional tone, explaining how to list and authorize a device, particularly a phone, for software installation by stating "you're going to see that your device is listed...LGMS that's my phone...unauthorized simply unplug your phone". The speaker then details the actions to take, including typing certain commands, and the implications of setting an install location. Finally, he concludes and states that the browser window should be closed.

The audio clip begins with speech from a single male speaker. He sounds instructional, indicating the listener is done and will see changes after he moves back to his phone. Following this, there's a brief interjection of speech by the same speaker indicating the end of the recording.

The clip begins with one male speaker discussing how to unplug a phone from a computer and move an app to an SD card. He then proceeds to unlock the phone and navigate the phone settings to the app section to find "Flappy Bird". Before this speaker can continue, an incidental sound of something being dropped interrupts him. The audio concludes with this speaker referring to the game, "Flappy Bird", and how it has moved to an SD card.

The clip begins with a male speaker excitedly explaining how to move apps to an SD card. He confidently states that any app from the Google Play store will automatically install to the SD card. He then searches for an app to install, mentioning he wants to avoid anything "stupid," and decides on "Smove." An installation proceeds, destined for the SD card. The speaker briefly gets antsy, but the installation completes successfully. The speaker excitedly states that once all apps are installed, they can be moved to the SD card, saving space on internal storage.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a video and expressing hope that viewers enjoyed it. He encourages listeners to let him know if they found it helpful and looks forward to his next video, possibly a commentary. The speaker ends with "thanks, bye". Subsequently, upbeat electronic music with a heavy bassline and synths starts, seemingly unrelated to the previous content.
